<!-- Generated by Harlequin Webmaker 2.1.3; Transducer 1.0.2 --> <HTML> <HEAD> <TITLE> Multiresolution Object Recognition</TITLE> </HEAD> <BODY> <A NAME=HEADING88></A> <A HREF="AR95Book-89.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bnext.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-87.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bprev.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-66.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bup.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-1.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Btop.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-2.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bcontent.gif"></A><BR><A HREF="AR95Book-89.html">[Next] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-87.html">[Previous] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-66.html">[Up] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-1.html">[Top] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-2.html">[Contents]</A> <P> <A NAME=HEADING88-0></A> <H1> Multiresolution Object Recognition</H1> Principal Investigator: <A HREF=AR95Book-22.html>Concettina Guerra</A><P> <IMG SRC="goldRule.gif" width =100%> <P> The purpose of this research is the development of efficient strategies for multi-resolution object recognition. Multiresolution approaches are often used in computer vision, especially for tasks that are high computation intensive. We study the problem of recognizing two-dimensional objects described in multi-resolution by labeled trees and formulate the matching problem as an approximate tree matching problem. Sequential and parallel solutions to this problem are investigated.<P> <IMG SRC="goldRule.gif" width =100%> <ADDRESS>CS Annual Report - 19 APR 1996</ADDRESS> <A HREF="AR95Book-89.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bnext.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-87.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bprev.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-66.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bup.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-1.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Btop.gif"></A><A HREF="AR95Book-2.html"><IMG ALIGN = BOTTOM SRC = "Bcontent.gif"></A><BR><A HREF="AR95Book-89.html">[Next] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-87.html">[Previous] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-66.html">[Up] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-1.html">[Top] </A><A HREF="AR95Book-2.html">[Contents]</A> <P> </BODY> </HTML> </HTML>
